newsitem.title: USA: FCC eases way for utilities to offer phone service.
newsitem.headline: FCC eases way for utilities to offer phone service.

text.p: The Federal Communications Commission Thursday simplified its procedures for allowing utilities to offer phone and other telecommunications services.

The rules implement the landmark telecommunications law enacted earlier this year. That law permits registered public utility holding companies to enter the telecommunications business -- without prior approval from the Securities and Exchange Commission -- by acquiring or maintaining an interest in a so-called "exempt telecommunications company," or ETC.
The FCC has the power to determine whether a company warrants ETC status.

The agency's new rules require applicants seeking that status to file with the agency a brief description of their planned activities together with a sworn statement attesting to any facts or representations presented to demonstrate ETC status as defined in the 1996 law.
Since the new law was enacted in February, the FCC has received 15 applications seeking ETC status and has approved 13 of those bids. Two are still pending.
